items.content_html: Been a long time. One rule people in tech like to try to follow or recommend is the 3-2-1 rule. If you don’t know it, it’s to keep 3 copies of your data, on at least 2 different media types like an external drive some Cloud account, and, at least 1 being off site.
items.content_text: Been a long time. One rule people in tech like to try to follow or recommend is the 3-2-1 rule. If you don't know it, it's to keep 3 copies of your data, on at least 2 different media types like an external drive some Cloud account, and, at least 1 being off site.

items.content_html: If you use brew, upgrading to MacOS 11.0.1 Big Sur results in errors regarding “CLT” (Xcode’s Command Line Tools), with commands like brew upgrade. Fix this situation by deleting and reinstalling CLT. https://logr.cogley.info/2020/11/15/1605445406/
items.content_text: If you use `brew`, upgrading to MacOS 11.0.1 Big Sur results in errors regarding "CLT" (Xcode's Command Line Tools), with commands like `brew upgrade`. Fix this situation by deleting and reinstalling CLT. https://logr.cogley.info/2020/11/15/1605445406/

items.title: M1 chipped Apples limited
items.content_html: The new Macs with Apple’s M1 chips indeed “change everything” as Apple says. You cannot use more than 1 external display on the laptops, although you can use 2 on the Mini since there’s an hdmi port apparently. Is this a way to sell the eye-wateringly expensive Mac Pro to desktop users?

items.content_html: June 18th is onigiri day in Japan. The 6th month was chosen because a fossilized Yayoi period rice ball was found in Rokusei-machi, in Ishikawa, and “roku” rhymes with 6. The 18 comes from the kanji “kome” ç±³, which broken down, looks like 10 and 8. ğŸ™

items.content_html: Heard about a Florida man who recently got killed by his Cassowary bird. These are large (as big as a person), territorial birds native to NE Australia and Papua New Guinea, that can become aggressive and can do real damage with their ~125mm claws if they kick you.
items.content_text: Heard about a Florida man who recently got killed by his [Cassowary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cassowary) bird. These are large (as big as a person), territorial birds native to NE Australia and Papua New Guinea, that can become aggressive and can do real damage with their ~125mm claws if they kick you.

items.content_html: Japan onsen springs' odd cultural habit of blanket-refusing service to anyone with a tattoo, while understandable (original concept was that yakuza baddies had them), is these days like refusing sauna service to anyone wearing a gold chain, or who says “yo”.
items.content_text: Japan onsen springs' odd cultural habit of blanket-refusing service to anyone with a tattoo, while understandable (original concept was that yakuza baddies had them), is these days like refusing sauna service to anyone wearing a gold chain, or who says "yo".

items.title: JR Sui-sui Suica Card lets you swim like a Penguin
items.content_html: JRâ€™s IC rail pass “Suica” is so named because it helps daily commuters pass through gates easily, i.e. in a “Sui-Sui” manner, since 2001. Penguins are skillful swimmers, passing in and around obstacles with ease, so thatâ€™s why the “Suica Penguin” mascot was born. Its designer is the lovely Chiharu Sakazaki å‚å´åƒæ˜¥, who modeled it after an AdÃ©lie penguin. Ironically, people shuffling towards escalators during rush hour, walk a lot like penguins. ğŸ§ğŸš…

items.title: Nissan board: who us?
items.content_html: Nissanâ€™s a huge company, not a corner mom-and-pop, so Ghosn being put forward as the primary evildoer as he rots in detention, and the innocent “who me” looks and whistling of the rest of the board (Japanese folks, don’t you know), is wildly disingenuous. Ghosn barely even speaks Japanese.

items.content_html: Tokyo weather has been super weird. It was like spring last week (cicadas even came out in places) and then the temps dropped to winter cold again. Well, at least I can take solace in Carrot app goading me about it. It’s like a demigod, or a snarkier version of my wife. :-p

Well, at least I can take solace in [Carrot](http://www.meetcarrot.com/weather/) app goading me about it. It's like a demigod, or a snarkier version of my wife. :-p

items.content_html: Nov 3 is “Culture Day” in Japan. Once Emperor Meiji’s birthday, the post-WWII constitution was promulgated on this day, so it is now a day to celebrate peace and culture.

items.content_html: Pretty terra cotta colored house in #totsuka #yokohama #japan. One thing you see in Japan that you might not see elsewhere, is a lot of laundry hanging out. People like to conserve electricity and hang laundry when possible, as well as their futons (you put it over the veranda rail). I hear that when Japanese go to other countries and hang their laundry out, itâ€™s often complained about. Whatâ€™s the status in your country? Do people hang out laundry?

items.content_html: #Anpanman playground equipment in #Yokohama #Japan. Anpanman is a superhero, who lets the weak or hungry eat part of his bean-jam-bun (anpan) head when they call him (he has great hearing and can hear anyone in the world), and can deliver a mighty an-punch or an-kick to his mortal enemy â€œbaikin manâ€ (bacteria man). The creator came up with Anpanman, apparently after starving in WWII and dreaming of bean jam buns. Anpanmanâ€™s weakness? Water or moistness. When his head gets wet, he gets weak. But never fear, Uncle Jam will bake him a new head in no time. We watched this show so many times with our daughters that I can sing the songs by heart.

items.content_html:
In #Japan, elementary school kids conduct interviews with shopkeepers, to learn a bit about what their jobs are like. Hereâ€™s a class visiting a fishmonger, in #Totsuka #Yokohama. I remember our daughters did this.

A neat aspect is all the signs, saying what kind of fish is available and that itâ€™s â€œdirect from Misakiâ€ which is the tip of the Miura Peninsula near where the Yokosuka military base is. Also, to the front right, you can get raw oysters and â€œOK to eat them standing right here!â€ I think Iâ€™ll try it next time.

items.content_html: Totsuka high school had their school matsuri festival (called gakusai or bunkasai å­¦ç¥­ã€æ–‡åŒ–ç¥­), with this pretty â€œwashiâ€ papered entrance prepared especially for the day. Kids put on skits and do activities all day, and itâ€™s attended by alums, parents, teachers, friends. The ones our girls did at their school were always a lot of fun. The character you can see on the gate looks like â€œwaâ€ (å’Œ), or peace/harmony. Itâ€™s kind of meta, with the right part of the character morphing into a circle, also a symbol for harmony and togetherness. #hope
